doc.title: Tree-Puzzle

description.text: Maximum likelihood analysis for nucleotide, amino-acid and two state data

doc.authors: Heiko A. Schmidt, Korbinian Strimmer and Arndt von Haeseler
doc.reference: Strimmer, K., and A. von Haeseler. 1996. Quartet puzzling:A quartet maximum likelihood method for reconstructing tree topologies. Mol. Biol. Evol. 13: 964-969.

xhtml:div.label:
Type of analysis? (b)?
Tree reconstruction Likelihood mapping
Allows to switch between tree reconstruction/analysis by maximum likelihood and likelihood mapping.

fieldset.legend: Both Tree reconstruction and Likelihood mapping options

xhtml:div.label:
Parameter estimates? (e)?
Approximate (faster) Exact (slow)
Determines whether an approximate or the exact likelihood function is used to estimate parameters of the models of sequence evolution. The approximate likelihood function is in most cases sufficient and is faster.

Parameter estimation uses? (x)?
Neighbor-joining tree Quartet sampling + NJ tree
Selects the methods used in the estimation of the model parameters. Neighbor-joining tree means that a NJ tree is used to estimate the parameters. Quartet sampling means that a number of random sets of four sequences are selected to estimate parameters.

Number of quartets? (n)?
If tree reconstruction is selected: number of puzzling steps. Parameter of the quartet puzzling tree search. Generally, the more sequences are used the more puzzling steps are advised. The default value varies depending on the number of sequences (at least 1000).If likelihood mapping is selected: number of qua rtets in a likelihood mapping analysis. Equal to the number of dots in the likelihood mapping diagram. By default 10000 dots/quartets are assumed. To use all possible quartets in clustered likelihood mapping you have to specify a value of n=0.

Tree search procedure? (k)?
Quartet puzzling Evaluate user defined trees Consensus of user defined trees Pairwise distances only (no tree)
Determines how the overall tree is obtained. The topology is either computed with the quartet puzzling algorithm or a set of trees is provided by the user. If there are more than two trees in such a set, maximum likelihood branch lengths will be computed for this tree and a number of tests (KH-test, SH-test, and ELW) will be performed on the trees by default. Instead of the evaluation a consensus can be computed for all the trees for which ML branch lengths and ML value are estimated. Alternatively, a maximum likelihood distance matrix only can also be computed (no overall tree).

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Compute clocklike branch lengths? (z)?
Yes No
Computation of clock-like maximum likelihood branch lengths. This option also invokes the likelihood ratio clock test.

Enter an invalid branch number to search for the best location despite of automatic search (l)?
Location of root. Only for computation of clock-like maximum likelihood branch lengths. Allows to specify the branch where the root should be placed in an unrooted tree topology. For example, in the tree (a,b,(c,d)) l = 1 places the root at the branch leading to sequence a whereas l=5 places the root at the internal branch.

Approximate quartet likelihood (v)?
Yes No
For the quartet puzzling tree search only. Only for very small data sets it is necessary to compute an exact maximum likelihood. For larger data sets this option should always be turned on.

List unresolved quartets? (u)?
Yes No
Show unresolved quartets. During the quartet puzzling tree search TREE-PUZZLE counts the number of unresolved quartet trees. An unresolved quartet is a quartet where the maximum likelihood values for each of the three possible quartet topologies are so similar that it is not possible to prefer one of them (Strimmer et al., 1997). If this option is selected you will get a detailed list of all star-like quartets. Note, for some data sets there may be a lot of unresolved quartets. In this case a list of all unresolved quartets is probably not very useful and also needs a lot of disk space.

Number of puzzling steps (n)?
If tree reconstruction is selected: number of puzzling steps. Parameter of the quartet puzzling tree search. Generally, the more sequences are used the more puzzling steps are advised. The default value varies depending on the number of sequences (at least 1000).If likelihood mapping is selected: number of quartets in a likelihood mapping analysis. Equal to the number of dots in the likelihood mapping diagram. By default 10000 dots/quartets are assumed. To use all possible quartets in clustered likelihood mapping you have to specify a value of n=0.

List puzzling step trees? (j)?
No Unique topologies Unique topologies & Chronological list Chronological list only
Writes all intermediate trees (puzzling step trees) used to compute the quartet puzzling tree into a file, either as a list of topologies ordered by number of occurrences (*.ptorder), or as list about the chronological occurrence of the topologies (*.pstep), or both.

Display as outgroup? (o) ?
For displaying purposes of the unrooted quartet puzzling tree only. The default outgroup is the first sequence of the data set.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory

xhtml:div.label:
Type of sequence input data? (d)?
Nucleotides Amino acids
Specifies whether nucleotide, amino acid sequences, or twostate data serve as input. The default is automatically set by inspection of the input data. After TREE-PUZZLE has selected an appropriate data type (marked by ?Auto:?) the ?d?-option changes the type in the following order: automatically selected type ! Nucleotides ! Amino acids ! automatically selected type.

Model of substitution for protein (m)?
Dayhoff (Dayhoff et al. 1978) JTT (Jones et al. 1992) mtREV24 (Adachi-Hasegawa 1996) BLOSUM 62 (Henikoff-Henikoff 1992) VT (Mueller-Vingron 2000) WAG (Whelan-Goldman 2000)
For amino acid sequence data the Dayhoff et al. (Dayhoff) model, the Jones et al. (JTT) model, the Adachi and Hasegawa (mtREV24) model, the Henikoff and Henikoff (BLOSUM 62), the Muller and Vingron (VT), and theWhelan and Goldman (WAG) substitution model are implemented in TREE-PUZZLE.
The mtREV24 model describes the evolution of amino acids encoded on mtDNA, and BLOSUM 62 is for distantly related amino acid sequences, as well as the VT model.

Use specified Amino acid frequencies (in %) (f)?
Yes No
The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

fieldset.legend: Values of specified amino acid frequencies (in %)

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Model of substitution for DNA (m)?
HKY (Hasegawa et al. 1985) TN (Tamura-Nei 1993) GTR (e.g. Lanave et al. 1980) SH (e.g. Schoeniger-von Haeseler 1994)
The following models are implemented for nucleotides: the general time reversible model (Tavaree, 1986, GTR, e.g.,) model, the Tamura and Nei (TN) model, the Hasegawa et al. (HKY) model, and the Schroniger and von Haeseler (SH) model.
The SH model describes the evolution of pairs of dependent nucleotides (pairs are the first and the second nucleotide, the third and the fourth nucleotide and so on). It allows for specification of the transition-transversion ratio.
The original model (Schroniger and von Haeseler, 1994) is obtained by setting the transition-transversion parameter to 0.5.
The Jukes and Cantor (1969), the Felsenstein (1981), and the Kimura (1980) model are all special cases of the HKY model.

Symmetrize doublet frequencies (s)?
Yes No
This option is only available for the SH model. With this option the doublet frequencies are symmetrized. For example, the frequencies of ?AT? and ?TA? are then set to the average of both frequencies.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label:
Constrain TN model to F84 model (p)?
Yes No
This option is only available for the Tamura-Nei model. With this option the expected (!) transition-transversion ratio for the F84 model have to be entered and TREE-PUZZLE computes the corresponding parameters of the TN model (this depends on base frequencies of the data). This allows to compare the results of TREE-PUZZLE and the PHYLIP maximum likelihood programs which use the F84 model.
Expected F84 Transition/transversion ratio

Y/R transition parameter (r)?
This option is only available for the TN model. This parameter is the ratio of the rates for pyrimidine transitions and purine transitions. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. For precise definition please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution.

Transition/transversion ratio (t)?
For nucleotide data only. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. The precise definition of this parameter is given in the section on models of sequence evolution in this manual.

Use specified values??
Yes No
The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: pi (A)

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: pi (C)

label.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.label: pi (G)

Model of rate heterogeneity (w)?
Uniform rate Gamma distributed rates Two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable) Mixed (1 invariable + n Gamma rates)
TREE-PUZZLE provides several different models of rate heterogeneity: uniform rate over all sites (rate homogeneity), Gamma distributed rates, two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable), and a mixed model (1 invariable rate + Gamma distributed rates). All necessary parameters can be estimated by TREE-PUZZLE. Note that whenever invariable sites are taken into account the parameter estimation will invoke the ?e? option to use an exact likelihood function. For more detailed information please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution. See also option ?m? (model of substitution).

Gamma rate heterogeneity parameter alpha (a)?
This is the so-called shape parameter of the Gamma distribution.

Number of Gamma rate categories (c)?
Number of rate categories (4-16) for the discrete Gamma distribution (rate heterogeneity).

Fraction of invariable sites (i)?
Probability of a site to be invariable. This parameter can be estimated from the data by TREE-PUZZLE (only if the approximation option for the likelihood function is turned off).

div.title: This parameter is mandatory

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Allows to switch between tree reconstruction/analysis by maximum likelihood and likelihood mapping.

xhtml:fieldset.xhtml:legend: Both Tree reconstruction and Likelihood mapping options

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Determines whether an approximate or the exact likelihood function is used to estimate parameters of the models of sequence evolution. The approximate likelihood function is in most cases sufficient and is faster.

Selects the methods used in the estimation of the model parameters. Neighbor-joining tree means that a NJ tree is used to estimate the parameters. Quartet sampling means that a number of random sets of four sequences are selected to estimate parameters.

If tree reconstruction is selected: number of puzzling steps. Parameter of the quartet puzzling tree search. Generally, the more sequences are used the more puzzling steps are advised. The default value varies depending on the number of sequences (at least 1000).If likelihood mapping is selected: number of qua rtets in a likelihood mapping analysis. Equal to the number of dots in the likelihood mapping diagram. By default 10000 dots/quartets are assumed. To use all possible quartets in clustered likelihood mapping you have to specify a value of n=0.

Determines how the overall tree is obtained. The topology is either computed with the quartet puzzling algorithm or a set of trees is provided by the user. If there are more than two trees in such a set, maximum likelihood branch lengths will be computed for this tree and a number of tests (KH-test, SH-test, and ELW) will be performed on the trees by default. Instead of the evaluation a consensus can be computed for all the trees for which ML branch lengths and ML value are estimated. Alternatively, a maximum likelihood distance matrix only can also be computed (no overall tree).

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Computation of clock-like maximum likelihood branch lengths. This option also invokes the likelihood ratio clock test.

Location of root. Only for computation of clock-like maximum likelihood branch lengths. Allows to specify the branch where the root should be placed in an unrooted tree topology. For example, in the tree (a,b,(c,d)) l = 1 places the root at the branch leading to sequence a whereas l=5 places the root at the internal branch.
For the quartet puzzling tree search only. Only for very small data sets it is necessary to compute an exact maximum likelihood. For larger data sets this option should always be turned on.

Show unresolved quartets. During the quartet puzzling tree search TREE-PUZZLE counts the number of unresolved quartet trees. An unresolved quartet is a quartet where the maximum likelihood values for each of the three possible quartet topologies are so similar that it is not possible to prefer one of them (Strimmer et al., 1997). If this option is selected you will get a detailed list of all star-like quartets. Note, for some data sets there may be a lot of unresolved quartets. In this case a list of all unresolved quartets is probably not very useful and also needs a lot of disk space.

If tree reconstruction is selected: number of puzzling steps. Parameter of the quartet puzzling tree search. Generally, the more sequences are used the more puzzling steps are advised. The default value varies depending on the number of sequences (at least 1000).If likelihood mapping is selected: number of quartets in a likelihood mapping analysis. Equal to the number of dots in the likelihood mapping diagram. By default 10000 dots/quartets are assumed. To use all possible quartets in clustered likelihood mapping you have to specify a value of n=0.

Writes all intermediate trees (puzzling step trees) used to compute the quartet puzzling tree into a file, either as a list of topologies ordered by number of occurrences (*.ptorder), or as list about the chronological occurrence of the topologies (*.pstep), or both.
For displaying purposes of the unrooted quartet puzzling tree only. The default outgroup is the first sequence of the data set.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Specifies whether nucleotide, amino acid sequences, or twostate data serve as input. The default is automatically set by inspection of the input data. After TREE-PUZZLE has selected an appropriate data type (marked by ?Auto:?) the ?d?-option changes the type in the following order: automatically selected type ! Nucleotides ! Amino acids ! automatically selected type.

For amino acid sequence data the Dayhoff et al. (Dayhoff) model, the Jones et al. (JTT) model, the Adachi and Hasegawa (mtREV24) model, the Henikoff and Henikoff (BLOSUM 62), the Muller and Vingron (VT), and theWhelan and Goldman (WAG) substitution model are implemented in TREE-PUZZLE.
The mtREV24 model describes the evolution of amino acids encoded on mtDNA, and BLOSUM 62 is for distantly related amino acid sequences, as well as the VT model.

The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

The SH model describes the evolution of pairs of dependent nucleotides (pairs are the first and the second nucleotide, the third and the fourth nucleotide and so on). It allows for specification of the transition-transversion ratio.
The original model (Schroniger and von Haeseler, 1994) is obtained by setting the transition-transversion parameter to 0.5.
The Jukes and Cantor (1969), the Felsenstein (1981), and the Kimura (1980) model are all special cases of the HKY model.

This option is only available for the SH model. With this option the doublet frequencies are symmetrized. For example, the frequencies of ?AT? and ?TA? are then set to the average of both frequencies.

This allows to compare the results of TREE-PUZZLE and the PHYLIP maximum likelihood programs which use the F84 model.

This option is only available for the TN model. This parameter is the ratio of the rates for pyrimidine transitions and purine transitions. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. For precise definition please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution.

For nucleotide data only. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. The precise definition of this parameter is given in the section on models of sequence evolution in this manual.

The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

All necessary parameters can be estimated by TREE-PUZZLE. Note that whenever invariable sites are taken into account the parameter estimation will invoke the ?e? option to use an exact likelihood function. For more detailed information please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution. See also option ?m? (model of substitution).

Display as outgroup? (o) ?
For displaying purposes of the unrooted quartet puzzling tree only. The default outgroup is the first sequence of the data set.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: For displaying purposes of the unrooted quartet puzzling tree only. The default outgroup is the first sequence of the data set.

comment.text: Specifies whether nucleotide, amino acid sequences, or twostate data serve as input. The default is automatically set by inspection of the input data. After TREE-PUZZLE has selected an appropriate data type (marked by ?Auto:?) the ?d?-option changes the type in the following order: automatically selected type ! Nucleotides ! Amino acids ! automatically selected type.

interface.label:
Type of sequence input data? (d)?
Nucleotides Amino acids
Specifies whether nucleotide, amino acid sequences, or twostate data serve as input. The default is automatically set by inspection of the input data. After TREE-PUZZLE has selected an appropriate data type (marked by ?Auto:?) the ?d?-option changes the type in the following order: automatically selected type ! Nucleotides ! Amino acids ! automatically selected type.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Specifies whether nucleotide, amino acid sequences, or twostate data serve as input. The default is automatically set by inspection of the input data. After TREE-PUZZLE has selected an appropriate data type (marked by ?Auto:?) the ?d?-option changes the type in the following order: automatically selected type ! Nucleotides ! Amino acids ! automatically selected type.

comment.text: For amino acid sequence data the Dayhoff et al. (Dayhoff) model, the Jones et al. (JTT) model, the Adachi and Hasegawa (mtREV24) model, the Henikoff and Henikoff (BLOSUM 62), the Muller and Vingron (VT), and theWhelan and Goldman (WAG) substitution model are implemented in TREE-PUZZLE.
The mtREV24 model describes the evolution of amino acids encoded on mtDNA, and BLOSUM 62 is for distantly related amino acid sequences, as well as the VT model.

interface.label:
Model of substitution for protein (m)?
Dayhoff (Dayhoff et al. 1978) JTT (Jones et al. 1992) mtREV24 (Adachi-Hasegawa 1996) BLOSUM 62 (Henikoff-Henikoff 1992) VT (Mueller-Vingron 2000) WAG (Whelan-Goldman 2000)
For amino acid sequence data the Dayhoff et al. (Dayhoff) model, the Jones et al. (JTT) model, the Adachi and Hasegawa (mtREV24) model, the Henikoff and Henikoff (BLOSUM 62), the Muller and Vingron (VT), and theWhelan and Goldman (WAG) substitution model are implemented in TREE-PUZZLE.
The mtREV24 model describes the evolution of amino acids encoded on mtDNA, and BLOSUM 62 is for distantly related amino acid sequences, as well as the VT model.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: For amino acid sequence data the Dayhoff et al. (Dayhoff) model, the Jones et al. (JTT) model, the Adachi and Hasegawa (mtREV24) model, the Henikoff and Henikoff (BLOSUM 62), the Muller and Vingron (VT), and theWhelan and Goldman (WAG) substitution model are implemented in TREE-PUZZLE.
The mtREV24 model describes the evolution of amino acids encoded on mtDNA, and BLOSUM 62 is for distantly related amino acid sequences, as well as the VT model.

comment.text: The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

interface.label:
Use specified Amino acid frequencies (in %) (f)?
Yes No
The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

comment.text: The following models are implemented for nucleotides: the general time reversible model (Tavaree, 1986, GTR, e.g.,) model, the Tamura and Nei (TN) model, the Hasegawa et al. (HKY) model, and the Schroniger and von Haeseler (SH) model.

The SH model describes the evolution of pairs of dependent nucleotides (pairs are the first and the second nucleotide, the third and the fourth nucleotide and so on). It allows for specification of the transition-transversion ratio.
The original model (Schroniger and von Haeseler, 1994) is obtained by setting the transition-transversion parameter to 0.5.
The Jukes and Cantor (1969), the Felsenstein (1981), and the Kimura (1980) model are all special cases of the HKY model.

interface.label:
Model of substitution for DNA (m)?
HKY (Hasegawa et al. 1985) TN (Tamura-Nei 1993) GTR (e.g. Lanave et al. 1980) SH (e.g. Schoeniger-von Haeseler 1994)
The following models are implemented for nucleotides: the general time reversible model (Tavaree, 1986, GTR, e.g.,) model, the Tamura and Nei (TN) model, the Hasegawa et al. (HKY) model, and the Schroniger and von Haeseler (SH) model.
The SH model describes the evolution of pairs of dependent nucleotides (pairs are the first and the second nucleotide, the third and the fourth nucleotide and so on). It allows for specification of the transition-transversion ratio.
The original model (Schroniger and von Haeseler, 1994) is obtained by setting the transition-transversion parameter to 0.5.
The Jukes and Cantor (1969), the Felsenstein (1981), and the Kimura (1980) model are all special cases of the HKY model.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The following models are implemented for nucleotides: the general time reversible model (Tavaree, 1986, GTR, e.g.,) model, the Tamura and Nei (TN) model, the Hasegawa et al. (HKY) model, and the Schroniger and von Haeseler (SH) model.

The SH model describes the evolution of pairs of dependent nucleotides (pairs are the first and the second nucleotide, the third and the fourth nucleotide and so on). It allows for specification of the transition-transversion ratio.
The original model (Schroniger and von Haeseler, 1994) is obtained by setting the transition-transversion parameter to 0.5.
The Jukes and Cantor (1969), the Felsenstein (1981), and the Kimura (1980) model are all special cases of the HKY model.

comment.text: This option is only available for the SH model. With this option the doublet frequencies are symmetrized. For example, the frequencies of ?AT? and ?TA? are then set to the average of both frequencies.

interface.label:
Symmetrize doublet frequencies (s)?
Yes No
This option is only available for the SH model. With this option the doublet frequencies are symmetrized. For example, the frequencies of ?AT? and ?TA? are then set to the average of both frequencies.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option is only available for the SH model. With this option the doublet frequencies are symmetrized. For example, the frequencies of ?AT? and ?TA? are then set to the average of both frequencies.

parameter.name: constrain_TN
parameter.prompt: Constrain TN model to F84 model (p)

comment.text: This option is only available for the Tamura-Nei model. With this option the expected (!) transition-transversion ratio for the F84 model have to be entered and TREE-PUZZLE computes the corresponding parameters of the TN model (this depends on base frequencies of the data). This allows to compare the results of TREE-PUZZLE and the PHYLIP maximum likelihood programs which use the F84 model.

interface.label:
Constrain TN model to F84 model (p)?
Yes No
This option is only available for the Tamura-Nei model. With this option the expected (!) transition-transversion ratio for the F84 model have to be entered and TREE-PUZZLE computes the corresponding parameters of the TN model (this depends on base frequencies of the data). This allows to compare the results of TREE-PUZZLE and the PHYLIP maximum likelihood programs which use the F84 model.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option is only available for the Tamura-Nei model. With this option the expected (!) transition-transversion ratio for the F84 model have to be entered and TREE-PUZZLE computes the corresponding parameters of the TN model (this depends on base frequencies of the data). This allows to compare the results of TREE-PUZZLE and the PHYLIP maximum likelihood programs which use the F84 model.

comment.text: This option is only available for the TN model. This parameter is the ratio of the rates for pyrimidine transitions and purine transitions. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. For precise definition please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution.

interface.label:
Y/R transition parameter (r)?
This option is only available for the TN model. This parameter is the ratio of the rates for pyrimidine transitions and purine transitions. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. For precise definition please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This option is only available for the TN model. This parameter is the ratio of the rates for pyrimidine transitions and purine transitions. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. For precise definition please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution.

comment.text: For nucleotide data only. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. The precise definition of this parameter is given in the section on models of sequence evolution in this manual.

interface.label:
Transition/transversion ratio (t)?
For nucleotide data only. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. The precise definition of this parameter is given in the section on models of sequence evolution in this manual.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: For nucleotide data only. You do not need to specify this parameter as TREE-PUZZLE estimates it from the data. The precise definition of this parameter is given in the section on models of sequence evolution in this manual.

comment.text: The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

Use specified values??
Yes No
The maximum likelihood calculation needs the frequency of each nucleotide (amino acid, doublet) as input. TREE-PUZZLE estimates these values from the sequence input data. This option allows specification of other values.

div.title: This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.
This parameter is mandatory under certain conditions.

comment.text: TREE-PUZZLE provides several different models of rate heterogeneity: uniform rate over all sites (rate homogeneity), Gamma distributed rates, two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable), and a mixed model (1 invariable rate + Gamma distributed rates). All necessary parameters can be estimated by TREE-PUZZLE. Note that whenever invariable sites are taken into account the parameter estimation will invoke the ?e? option to use an exact likelihood function. For more detailed information please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution. See also option ?m? (model of substitution).

interface.label:
Model of rate heterogeneity (w)?
Uniform rate Gamma distributed rates Two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable) Mixed (1 invariable + n Gamma rates)
TREE-PUZZLE provides several different models of rate heterogeneity: uniform rate over all sites (rate homogeneity), Gamma distributed rates, two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable), and a mixed model (1 invariable rate + Gamma distributed rates). All necessary parameters can be estimated by TREE-PUZZLE. Note that whenever invariable sites are taken into account the parameter estimation will invoke the ?e? option to use an exact likelihood function. For more detailed information please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution. See also option ?m? (model of substitution).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: TREE-PUZZLE provides several different models of rate heterogeneity: uniform rate over all sites (rate homogeneity), Gamma distributed rates, two rates (1 invariable + 1 variable), and a mixed model (1 invariable rate + Gamma distributed rates). All necessary parameters can be estimated by TREE-PUZZLE. Note that whenever invariable sites are taken into account the parameter estimation will invoke the ?e? option to use an exact likelihood function. For more detailed information please read the section in this manual about models of sequence evolution. See also option ?m? (model of substitution).

comment.text: This is the so-called shape parameter of the Gamma distribution.

interface.label:
Gamma rate heterogeneity parameter alpha (a)?
This is the so-called shape parameter of the Gamma distribution.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This is the so-called shape parameter of the Gamma distribution.

format.code: ( "" , "c\n" + str(value) +"\n" )[ value is not None and value != vdef]

comment.text: Number of rate categories (4-16) for the discrete Gamma distribution (rate heterogeneity).

interface.label:
Number of Gamma rate categories (c)?
Number of rate categories (4-16) for the discrete Gamma distribution (rate heterogeneity).

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Number of rate categories (4-16) for the discrete Gamma distribution (rate heterogeneity).

comment.text: Probability of a site to be invariable. This parameter can be estimated from the data by TREE-PUZZLE (only if the approximation option for the likelihood function is turned off).

interface.label:
Fraction of invariable sites (i)?
Probability of a site to be invariable. This parameter can be estimated from the data by TREE-PUZZLE (only if the approximation option for the likelihood function is turned off).
